_link.title: I can apply E = VIt to calculate electrical energy in a circuit

toLevel2.question: Which formula is used to calculate electrical energy when current, voltage, and time are known?
In the formula E = VIt, what does V represent?
What unit is electrical energy measured in?
In E = VIt, what does the letter I represent?
What must time be measured in when using the formula E = VIt to calculate energy in joules?
The formula E = {{VIt}} calculates electrical {{energy}} in a circuit.
In E = VIt, V is potential difference, I is {{current}}, and t is {{time}}.
Electrical energy is measured in {{joules}}, while time must be in {{seconds}} for E = VIt.
The formula E = VIt combines V = E/Q and I = Q/t.
In E = VIt, time can be measured in hours without any conversion.

toLevel3.question: A device operates at 12 V with 3 A current for 100 seconds. What is the energy transferred?
Why is E = VIt practical for calculating energy consumption of appliances?
options: V and I can be measured directly with meters
toLevel3.answer: V and I can be measured directly with meters

toLevel3.question: A phone charger operates at 5 V with 2 A for 1 hour. How should time be expressed in the formula?
If a lamp uses 240 V, 0.5 A for 60 seconds, how much energy is consumed?
What happens to the energy transferred if the time is doubled while V and I remain constant?
A 9 V battery supplies 0.5 A for 200 seconds. What is the energy transferred?
A device at 10 V drawing 2 A for 50 s transfers E = 10 × 2 × 50 = {{1000}} J of energy.
The formula E = VIt is derived by combining V = E/Q with I = {{Q/t}}.
If voltage increases while current and time stay the same, the energy transferred {{increases}}.
A heater running at 240 V with 10 A for 60 seconds transfers 144,000 J of energy.

toLevel4.question: A phone charger operates at 5 V with 2 A current for 2 hours. What is the energy delivered?
An electric kettle operates at 2400 W for 3 minutes. Using P = VI and E = Pt, what is the energy used?
A laptop charger supplies 19 V at 3 A. How long must it run to deliver 34,200 J?
Two devices both operate for 100 s. Device A: 12 V, 2 A. Device B: 6 V, 4 A. Compare their energy consumption.
options: Device A uses twice as much
Device B uses twice as much

toLevel4.question: A car battery supplies 12 V at 50 A to start an engine for 4 seconds. How much energy is used?
An LED lamp operates at 12 V, 0.5 A. How many hours can it run on 21,600 J of energy?
A USB port supplies 5 V. If a device draws 0.5 A for 30 minutes, what is the energy delivered?
A 240 V heater drawing 10 A for 5 minutes (300 s) uses E = 240 × 10 × 300 = {{720,000}} J.
To find the time needed to transfer 1000 J at 10 V and 2 A, rearrange to t = E/(VI) = 1000/(10×2) = {{50}} s.
A 9 V device using 18,000 J in 1 hour draws a current of I = E/(Vt) = 18000/(9×3600) = {{0.56}} A.

toLevel5.question: A solar panel charges a 12 V battery with varying current: 2 A for 2 hours, then 1 A for 3 hours. What is the total energy stored?
An electric car battery stores 60 kWh. The motor operates at 400 V drawing 100 A. How long can the car run on a full charge?
A power bank rated at 10,000 mAh at 3.7 V. If it charges a phone at 5 V, 2 A, what is the maximum charging time?
Two heaters run for 1 hour. Heater A: 240 V, 10 A. Heater B: 120 V, 20 A. Which statement is correct?
options: Heater A transfers twice as much energy
Heater B transfers twice as much energy
Energy cannot be compared without resistance

toLevel5.question: A student claims that reducing voltage while keeping current and time constant will increase energy transfer. Is this correct?
options: No, reducing voltage decreases energy transfer
Yes, lower voltage means more efficient transfer
Voltage has no effect on energy
toLevel5.answer: No, reducing voltage decreases energy transfer

toLevel5.question: A factory motor operates at 400 V, 50 A for 8 hours daily. What is the daily energy consumption in kWh?
Electricity costs $0.25/kWh. A 240 V, 2000 W heater runs for 3 hours. What is the cost?
A battery can supply 12 V at 5 A for 2 hours before depleting. If the load changes to draw 10 A, how long will the battery last?
A power bank stores 37,000 J (10,000 mAh at 3.7 V). Charging at 5 V, 2 A, it can supply t = E/(VI) = 37000/(5×2) = {{3700}} seconds.
Comparing E = VIt with E = Pt, we can see that power P = {{VI}}, showing power is the rate of energy transfer.
